summary: DrawVertices outputs black triangle instead of colored gradient in v3 due to upstream Skia behavior change — default paint color (black) is now modulated with vertex colors

bugSignals.errorMessage: DrawVertices produces a solid black triangle instead of a gradient triangle with vertex colors

stepsToReproduce: Create an SKSurface with RGBA8888 color type
Create an SKPaint with IsAntialias = true (default color is black)
Call DrawVertices with SKVertexMode.Triangles, 3 vertices, and RGB colors (Red, Green, Blue)
Observe output is a solid black triangle instead of a gradient

versionAnalysis.relevanceReason: The DrawVertices overloads still hardcode SKBlendMode.Modulate, and Skia's behavior for drawVertices with opaque paint color has not changed back.

regression.reason: Upstream Skia changed how drawVertices interacts with the paint color. In newer Skia (used by SkiaSharp v3), drawVertices blends the paint's opaque color (src) with vertex colors (dst) using the blend mode. Since SkPaint defaults to opaque black and the blend mode is Modulate (src × dst), black × anything = black. Older Skia (used by v2.88) handled vertex colors differently.

analysis.summary: DrawVertices produces black output in SkiaSharp v3 because all convenience overloads hardcode SKBlendMode.Modulate, and Skia now modulates the paint's opaque color (default = black) with vertex colors. Black × any color = black.
analysis.rationale: This is a real regression from v2 to v3 caused by an upstream Skia behavior change in how drawVertices blends paint color with vertex colors. The SkiaSharp wrapper code itself hasn't changed — it still passes Modulate as the blend mode — but Skia now uses the paint's opaque color as the blend source. Since SKPaint defaults to opaque black {0,0,0,1}, and Modulate = src × dst, the result is always black. The area is core SkiaSharp (SKCanvas.DrawVertices), not views or native. Severity is medium because there's a straightforward workaround (set paint color to white), but it's a breaking change that affects all DrawVertices users who relied on v2 behavior.

keySignals.text: Passing in a color array works fine in v2.88.9 but after updating to 3.116.1 the output is simply black
keySignals.interpretation: Confirms regression — same code, different results between v2 and v3.
Default paint color is opaque black — this is the root cause when modulated with vertex colors.

keySignals.text: the opaque SkPaint color if SkPaint does not contain SkShader as the src of the blend and the interpolated vertex colors as the dst
keySignals.interpretation: Skia documentation confirms paint color is used as blend source for drawVertices when no shader is set.
All convenience overloads hardcode Modulate blend mode — no way to override without using the lower-level overload.

keySignals.text: This will give you the result you were after: Shader = SKShader.CreateColor(SKColors.White)
keySignals.interpretation: Community-provided workaround confirmed — setting a white shader makes modulate preserve vertex colors.

codeInvestigation.finding: All 3 convenience DrawVertices overloads hardcode SKBlendMode.Modulate. The 4th overload (line 930) accepts a blend mode parameter. The core method (line 936) passes vertices, mode, and paint directly to the C API.
SkPaint default constructor initializes fColor4f to {0,0,0,1} (opaque black). This is the src color for Modulate blending in drawVertices.
Skia docs specify: drawVertices combines 'the opaque SkPaint color' (when no shader) as src with 'interpolated vertex colors' as dst using the blend mode. Modulate = src × dst.
C API passes through to Skia's drawVertices without modification: AsCanvas(ccanvas)->drawVertices(AsVertices(vertices), (SkBlendMode)mode, *AsPaint(paint))
SKVertices.CreateCopy correctly passes vertex colors to Skia. No color transformation or loss occurs in the C# wrapper.

workarounds: Set paint.Color = SKColors.White before calling DrawVertices — white (1,1,1,1) modulated with vertex colors preserves the original colors
Set paint.Shader = SKShader.CreateColor(SKColors.White) to achieve the same result via a shader
Use the overload DrawVertices(SKVertexMode, SKPoint[], SKPoint[], SKColor[], SKBlendMode, UInt16[], SKPaint) with SKBlendMode.Dst to ignore paint color entirely
nextQuestions: Should SkiaSharp add a compatibility shim in the convenience overloads to default paint color to white when only vertex colors are provided?
Is this a deliberate upstream Skia change or an unintended side effect of Skia refactoring?
Should the SkiaSharp v3 migration guide document this behavior change?

resolution.hypothesis: Upstream Skia changed drawVertices blending semantics. The paint's opaque color is now used as the src in blend mode, and default SKPaint color is black. Modulate(black, vertex_color) = black.

proposals.title: Set paint color to white
proposals.description: The simplest workaround: set paint.Color = SKColors.White before calling DrawVertices. Since Modulate = src × dst, white (1,1,1,1) × vertex_color = vertex_color, preserving the original gradient.

proposals.title: Use white shader on paint
proposals.description: Set paint.Shader = SKShader.CreateColor(SKColors.White) to provide a white shader that gets modulated with vertex colors. Functionally equivalent to setting Color to white.

proposals.title: Use Dst blend mode
proposals.description: Use the lower-level DrawVertices overload with SKBlendMode.Dst to ignore the paint color entirely and render only vertex colors.
proposals.codeSnippet:
var vert = SKVertices.CreateCopy(SKVertexMode.Triangles, vertices, colors);
canvas.DrawVertices(vert, SKBlendMode.Dst, paint);

proposals.title: Document as v3 breaking change
proposals.description: Add this behavior change to the v3 migration guide. DrawVertices now requires paint color or shader to be set appropriately since Skia blends it with vertex colors via the blend mode.

resolution.recommendedReason: Simplest fix — one property change. Directly addresses the root cause (black paint color being modulated) without requiring API changes or overload switching.

actionability.reason: Root cause identified as upstream Skia behavior change. Workaround is trivial (set paint.Color = SKColors.White). Community comment already provided a working solution. Could alternatively keep open to track as a breaking change for documentation.

actions.comment:
Thanks for the clear repro — this is a behavior change in the upstream Skia library used by SkiaSharp v3.

In v3, `drawVertices` blends the paint's color (src) with vertex colors (dst) using the blend mode. The convenience `DrawVertices` overloads use `SKBlendMode.Modulate` (src × dst), and since `SKPaint` defaults to opaque black, the result is `black × vertex_color = black`.

Here's a workaround — set the paint color to white so modulate preserves vertex colors:

```csharp
var paint = new SKPaint
{
    IsAntialias = true,
    Color = SKColors.White
};
```

Alternatively, as @molesmoke noted, you can use `Shader = SKShader.CreateColor(SKColors.White)` which achieves the same result.

This is documented in the [Skia `drawVertices` API](https://api.skia.org/classSkCanvas.html): "the opaque SkPaint color if SkPaint does not contain SkShader as the src of the blend."
